The day had been tense with waiting. At dawn, Pietro's crew had deployed the single bombard at the siege works under Infante Enrique's watchful eye. The construction theater continued—axes biting into timber, stakes being sharpened, earthworks dug with deliberate slowness. Smoke from the fires drifted across the position, obscuring exact numbers. Don Pedro González moved between the formations, speaking quietly with commanders. Your heavy cavalry—4,000 mounted knights and men-at-arms—waited in their formations, lances vertical, the cream of Castilian chivalry.

The afternoon sun was beginning its descent when the first messenger galloped in from the cavalry screen to the south. The rider was covered in dust, his horse lathered. He was brought immediately to your position.

Don García Fernández de Baeza, commanding the southern cavalry screen, had sent urgent word: "Sultan's army approaching at speed. Not deploying—still in march column. Distance: six miles and closing. Estimate arrival within two hours. They show no signs of halting."

Less than thirty minutes later, a second rider: "Sultan's vanguard cavalry engaging our screening forces. Main body still advancing. They're pushing straight toward the siege works. No reconnaissance deployment—they're coming to fight NOW."

From your position, you could see the siege works clearly in the distance. The white banner with the True Cross hung from its pole, visible for miles. Infante Enrique's 5,000 were going about their construction work, apparently unaware—though you knew better. They were waiting.

Then, carried on the wind from the south, you heard it: drums. War drums, growing louder. The distant thunder of thousands of feet on the march.

Don Pedro González rode up beside you, his face grave. "Your Majesty, the Sultan is committing to immediate attack. His troops must be exhausted—they've marched forty miles in two days. He's throwing them straight at Enrique's position without rest or proper deployment."

From the siege works, you saw movement. Infante Enrique's troops were forming defensive lines, abandoning the construction theater. The single bombard crew scrambled to position the gun. The appearance of hasty, panicked preparation—exactly as planned—but you knew those were some of your best troops forming those lines.

The drums grew louder. On the southern horizon, you could now see movement—dark masses resolving into formations. Cavalry ranging ahead, infantry columns behind. The green banners of Granada, the black and gold of the Sultan's personal standard.

They were coming straight in.

April 1, 1431 - Late Afternoon
Battlefield North of Alcalá la Real

You rode at the head of your heavy cavalry, 4,000 mounted knights spreading wide to your flanks. The afternoon sun glinted off a forest of lance points and polished plate. Ahead and to your left, Don García Fernández's First Battle was advancing at the steady pace—5,000 infantry moving forward in their formations, banners streaming.

The Sultan's army was fully committed now. You could see them clearly across the open ground—dark masses of infantry pushing toward Infante Enrique's siege works, cavalry ranging on the flanks. The war drums thundered continuously, and you could hear distant shouts: "Allahu Akbar!" carried on the wind.

Your cavalry began the wide flanking arc, moving at a measured trot to preserve the horses. From your elevated position in the saddle, you had a commanding view of the developing battle.

Don García's First Battle reached the Sultan's left flank and crashed into contact. The sound was like thunder—thousands of men meeting in combat, the roar of war cries, the clang of steel. The lines merged into a churning mass of violence.

But something was wrong with the Moorish formations.

Even from this distance, you could see it. Where you expected to see disciplined infantry wheeling to meet García's flank attack, you saw... confusion. Hesitation. The Moorish left flank wasn't pivoting to engage—it was recoiling. Gaps were opening in their formations.

At the siege works, Infante Enrique's lines stood rock-solid behind their hasty earthworks. The Sultan's frontal assault was pushing forward, but slowly, without the momentum of a properly coordinated attack. Men were stumbling. You saw one Moorish formation simply... stop. Refuse to advance further. Officers were visible among them, gesturing frantically.

Your cavalry continued its arc. Pedro González's Second Battle was deploying now, 5,000 more infantry moving into the center. The Moorish army should have been wheeling, reforming, presenting a coherent defensive line against this massive threat.

They weren't.

Instead, you saw clusters of men standing still. Others backing away. One entire unit on the Sultan's right flank—maybe 500 men—broke from their formation and began moving rearward, not running but walking, simply abandoning their positions.
